Summary: I used to camp in O'Neill Park with my folks when I was a kid. Even though I lived just a few miles away. But I haven't been her in many years. I'm happy to see the many improvements. Asphalt  roads vs dirt throughouts,water at many of the sites, plenty of trash dumpers, completely remodeled restrooms with showers. It still has all the large oak trees. and the drive through Live Oak Canyon hasn't changed a bit. and it is still dry camping. No electrical or sewer hookups. We really enjoyed our stay there. It is very close to town and all the stores and restaurants. The hiking and horseback riding. But still out in the wilderness. So you still have to be aware of the wildlife. Including mountain lions. Be sure to make reservations.

Summary Heading: Felt safe and everyone was friendly
Summary: This was our first camping trip as a family, and it went really well at this campsite. We were close to bathrooms and showers. There was a security truck that would drive around periodically, which I appreciated. It's a very beautiful park and loved that my kids had such a great time.

We didn’t research enough and didn’t realize there were no hookups. You can only run your generator from 8am-8pm, but even then you feel like your annoying your neighbors in their tents so we tried to keep it off as much as possible. The “community water spigot” was too far away for our hose. So of course with no hookups, no internet or antenna TV as well.  We stayed one night and went to Orangeland RV Park. More money, but worth it for the hookups.

I reserved site 71 and we had friends in site 69, 73 & 75. Planned on having a large area to "spread out." When we got there my 19' trailer fit tight but even worse there was a huge California Oak right where my awning was going to be when I pulled it out. So our tent camping friends in 69 said it would be better to park on their site since they weren't using the asphalt portion. Sites are level for the most part. It was a whole story at the check-in to tell them we were just parking in two different sites. I guess they've had problems with that in the past. I offered to have both of us go to the front to switch parking passes. They were fine with it and let us do our thing for the weekend. My other camping neighbor left a light on and ran out of battery so I let him borrow our

Recent first time visit. Beautiful park with clean facilities. Friendly and helpful rangers. We were given a refund on our camping fees when I injured my back and we had to leave 2 days early. It does get very hot here in the summer. I am taking off one star because we were not informed of an annual and very huge biker rally. Rangers claimed it was on the website, which it was not. Note there are no hookups here. Nearby restaurants are Trabuco Steakhouse and Rose Canyon Cantina, both very popular.

Summary Heading: NATURAL HILL COUNTY PARK - SECURE, WELL-MAINTAINED, BEAUTIFUL AND AFFORDABLE
Summary: (No quick and easy way to get there) Located off of Live Oak Canyon Road in the Orange County hill country at the southeastern tip of the county and near the boundary of the Cleveland National Forest, the 4,000-acre O'NEILL REGIONAL PARK offers overnight campsites for tents and recreational vehicles, day use camp sites for large groups, picnic areas, restrooms, access to regional hiking trails (east to Saddleback Mountain and west to the ocean) with huge shade trees and well-maintained fields. This park is a year-round facility but is better enjoyed in the off-peak periods. It is best to avoid the hot and crowded months of June, July, and August. We like to take our guests with children there, where we set up a day camp and then we hike up into the Cleveland National Forest via
Room tip: Most of the overnight camp sites are good.

Summary: Stayed for the first time Veterans Day weekend. Good sites with space to pitch tent away from neighbours, far enough away their conversation and laughter were distant. I brought airplugs and used 'em.
Room tip: See layout of campground in-person or on a map, youll have the opportunity to select a site with...

Summary: Great campsite for kids! Each site has some amount of shade depending on the time of day and the sites are on the larger side, too. The bathrooms are clean and there's hot showers. At the entrance, there's a nature center where there are nature walks and kids' activities. Firewood can be purchased at the entrance. A little walk and you'll reach great trails - even the shortest (Edna Spaulding) has amazing views. There's a general store just down Trabuco Canyon and Ralph's is just a short drive away. A great site for beginning campers.
Room tip: If sensitive to street noise, try sites away from trabuco canyon rd.

Summary: Trails, forest, fresh air, stars at night and all at a remarkable price, just $20 or if you are a senior like me, $15. Unfortunately no power but water. Best Mexican restaurant around just a hop skip and jump away, Rose Canyon Cantina, italian lights around a giant tree surrounded by tables and drink rails.
Room tip: get a site early, they fill up fast in the summer and holidays including Christmas and Thanksgiving.

Summary: Stayed one night in March 2016  Spots are very spacious, each with a fire pit, picnic table and most have a water spout.   Most spots have some sort of shade or tree around.  Restrooms are pretty clean and the showers have warm water.   We stayed during the week and had no neighbors and the campground itself was quiet, though as many others point out you will hear the traffic from the road.    When you arrive at the park, you need to park and check in at the little ranger station.  It's fairly quick if you have online reservations.  The staff was friendly.    Coming and going is a little pain because they do have a parking gate that has to be opened each time.   Ralph's grocery store, Rite Aid and some food places are within 3 miles.

We recently stayed the night here in our Mercedes Sprinter coach. Although there were no hookups, there were clean bathrooms and hot showers available (despite the warning posted online that the showers were turned off due to the drought). There is a quaint little convenience store located just outside the park that sells a variety of craft beers. In the morning, we took the approximate three hour hike to the Vista Trail. The park is about nine miles from the Pacific, but you can see Catalina Island from the top of the trail.

Nice park to camp in. Dry camping other than water. Showers available, but need better cleaning so use water shoes. Campground gets crowded on weekends. Camp host a very nice guy and he is quick to act on any issue that may arise, like loud music.

Summary Heading: Quiet on the weekdays. Busy on the weekends.
Summary: Great camping area for RVs, campers, horses, bicycles, hiking and more. Showers and bathrooms fairly close to evert spot. There are water spigots around the park but not everywhere. Dog friendly as well. I would definitely recommend this park. The only noise we dealt with was the occasional motorcycle brigade, scouts and kids having fun and such, and the tree trimmers in the week (which I'm sure is only something one would experience if they happen to schedule during tree trimming week). All in all a very good stay and good accommodations, even with a schedule/spot conflict. - *TIP: Book weekends as far in advance as possible to avoid having to move around. - ~ABC

We went tent camping just for one night. We loved that you felt out in the middle of no where but there were conveniences near by if necessary. The facilities were clean and close by. Our site had plenty of space between us and our neighbor. We had a nice fire ring and picnic table. There was plenty of wilderness to walk through just on the other side of our camp. My only suggestion would be to make sure you get a site with a shade tree. It was very hot when we were there and we had no shade.

This was our first camping trip as a family.  My wife and I both camped when we were younger, so we thought we would take our boys and start a new family tradition.  We stayed in O'Neil Park, we put up our tent, we brought our camp stove and we camped.  We stayed three days and two nights. We went on a guided mile long hike that was awesome.  They have nice bathroom and shower facility, and very nice Park staff.  Each camp site has a fire pit, a bbg, a cement picnic table, and a place to park two vehicles.

My husband and I have been camping at O'Neill in Trabuco Canyon for 4 years. It's one of our favorite places to be. Ive been using tripadvisor and reading reviews for a couple years. I trust tripadvisor for honest opinions. I just signed up to write reviews myself (I dont know why I took so long). Anyways, I want to MAKE SURE that I add O'Neill  Regional Park Camping to our list of FAVORITES. So, as I said, we have been camping here for 4 years. We go at least twice a year, and we love that its like 30 minutes from our house. So we pack to camp, drive a bit, and we are there!  At O'neill, you feel like you are miles away from "the city", but its right around the corner (so if you need more hamburger buns, you can go to the market).  Here is the secrets to a perfect trip to

We have come here 2 yrs in a row to camp with a large Girl Scout group. We were camped at the very end at Hickey Creek. The campsite is very nice, bathrooms have flushing toilets and were well maintained. There were also showers which seemed clean and well maintained. There was plenty of tree coverage in the camping area which was nice when the days were hot. Nights in October are super cold so bring lots of extra blankets. There is a BBQ, fire pit and plenty of tables.   Few downfalls: noticed some of the individual campsites didn't have any shade so bringing an EZ Up would be recommended. Also, next door to where we camped there were chickens and other animals that made a lot of noise starting around 4am. There also seemed to be quite a bit of noise coming from the fire

Summary Heading: Rude Ranger ruins an otherwise 5 star place
Summary: Upon arrival we were greeting by a lady on their staff that clearly does not enjoy her job. We could only hope this was not the start of a terrible camping experience. While checking in the lady could not have been more rude or less informative as this was our first visit here.  We could hear the other lady working in the booth happily  greet other guests in the most friendly manner. Upon arrival to our campsite we discovered that the previous campers had left their trash including chairs and a tent, with various trash spread over the entire campsite. While we were surprised that such a mess was not cleaned upon arrival, we quickly flagged down a ranger who removed the chairs and tent but left the rest of the garbage for us to contend with. Otherwise we found the camp grounds to
